item.title: US Existing-Home Sales Decline, Marking Worst April Since 2009
item.description: US sales of previously owned homes unexpectedly dropped in April to the slowest pace in seven months, restrained by ongoing affordability constraints and highlighting a lackluster start to the key spring selling season.
item.dc:creator: Michael Sasso

media:content.media:description: Homes in Aldie, Virginia, US. Photographer: Nathan Howard/Bloomberg

item.title: South Africa Expects US Reset Despite White House Confrontation
item.description: South Africa’s finance chief said the government made progress on resetting its relationship with the US and securing a trade deal in talks that took place after President Cyril Ramaphosa’s showdown with Donald Trump at the White House.
item.dc:creator: Ntando Thukwana, S'thembile Cele

media:content.media:description: Enoch Godongwana

item.title: Carney Looks to AI for Savings as Canada’s Budget Pressures Mount
item.description: Prime Minister Mark Carney said Canada will begin to use artificial intelligence “at scale” to make the government more productive, as his administration looks for ways to squeeze out cost savings in a time of economic pressure.
item.dc:creator: Mathieu Dion, Derek Decloet

media:content.media:description: Mark Carney, Canada's prime minister, left, shakes hands with Francois-Philippe Champagne, Canada's finance minister, after a swearing-in ceremony at Rideau Hall in Ottawa, Ontario, Canada, on Tuesday, May 13, 2025. Carney's new cabinet includes a mix of familiar names and political rookies to carry out his ambitious economic agenda.

item.title: Egypt Makes Second Rate Cut in a Row Before Summer of Reforms
item.description: Egypt cut interest rates for the second time in as many months, seeking to boost economic growth before a likely fresh round of fiscal reforms this summer spurs renewed caution.
item.dc:creator: Mirette Magdy, Tarek El-Tablawy

item.title: ECB Must Stay Cautious Despite Inflation Nearing 2%, Nagel Says
item.description: The European Central Bank must remain vigilant, despite almost having returned inflation to 2%, Governing Council member Joachim Nagel said.
item.dc:creator: Kamil Kowalcze

media:content.media:description: Joachim Nagel

item.title: BOE’s Pill Questions Prominence of Forecasts in Era of Shocks
item.description: A combination of increasingly frequent economic shocks and unreliable data has made Bank of England forecasts less useful and the job of UK central bankers particularly “challenging” at the moment, Bank of England Chief Economist Huw Pill said.
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick, Irina Anghel

media:content.media:description: Huw Pill

item.title: Mexico Inflation and Growth Data Pave the Way for New Interest Rate Cut
item.description: Mexico’s annual inflation accelerated more than expected early this month in a report that likely won’t deter central bankers from cutting the interest rate again in June given the economy also posted weak growth.
item.dc:creator: Maya Averbuch, Alex Vasquez

media:content.media:description: Shoppers browse products at a Wal-Mart de Mexico store in Mexico City, Mexico.

item.title: US Business Activity, Sentiment Improve as Tariff Anxiety Eases
item.description: US business activity and output expectations improved this month as trade-related anxiety eased even as price pressures continued to mount due to tariffs.

media:content.media:description: Workers package a window frames at a manufacturing facility in Pella, Iowa.

item.title: G-7 Draft Warns of ‘Excessive Imbalances’ in Global Economy
item.description: Finance ministers and central bank governors from the Group of Seven nations pledged to address “excessive imbalances” in the global economy, an effort clearly aimed at China, though a draft communique seen by Bloomberg News omitted the name of the country.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley, Jorge Valero, William Horobin

media:content.media:description: Scott Bessent, US treasury secretary, during a House Financial Services Committee hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, May 7, 2025. Bessent said he’s working with US legislators on outbound investment rules for China that would make clear what’s allowed and what’s not.

item.title: Dimon Warns of US Stagflation Risk, Says Fed Right to Hold
item.description: Jamie Dimon said he can’t rule out the possibility of stagflation as the US grapples with huge risks from geopolitics, deficits and price pressures.
item.dc:creator: Ambereen Choudhury, Haslinda Amin

media:content.media:description: Jamie Dimon in Shanghai. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: BOE’s Dhingra Says UK Services Industry Was Hit Hard by Brexit
item.description: Bank of England rate-setter Swati Dhingra said there was new evidence that Brexit had dealt a bigger blow to Britain’s services trade than previously realized.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees

media:content.media:description: Swati Dhingra

item.title: Macron Talks Up China Ties and Touts Progress on Cognac
item.description: French President Emmanuel Macron is seeking to deepen economic ties with China as the European Union adjusts to the twin shocks of the American trade war and the continuing Russian invasion of Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: James Regan, Angelina Rascouet

media:content.media:description: Emmanuel Macron, right, and Xi Jinping in Paris in 2024.

item.title: Romania’s New Leader Urges Budget Fix as Top Government Goal
item.description: Romania’s newly-elected president expects several weeks of negotiations on a new government, saying the key focus needs to be on tackling the budget crisis and avoiding a credit rating downgrade.
item.dc:creator: Andra Timu, Irina Vilcu

media:content.media:description: Nicusor Dan addresses the Constitutional Court of Romanian after he received his mandate at Parliament Palace in Bucharest May 22.

item.title: Fed’s Waller Offers Route to Rate Cuts in Second Half of Year
item.description: Federal Reserve Governor Christopher Waller said the central bank could cut interest rates in the second half of 2025 if the Trump administration’s tariffs on US trading partners settle around 10%.
item.dc:creator: Amara Omeokwe

media:content.media:description: Christopher Waller, Federal Reserve governor

item.title: UK to Weigh CPI Data Overhaul to Better Gauge Inflation’s Path
item.description: The UK is looking at overhauling how it calculates one of its key inflation metrics to smooth out seasonal swings, according to people familiar with the matter. Such a move could help the Bank of England and investors better gauge the shifts in inflation pressures.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees

item.title: Turkey Central Bank Hits Hawkish Note in Inflation Outlook Hold
item.description: Turkey’s central bank stuck to its year-end inflation forecast and signaled that it’ll keep interest rates higher for longer to meet it.
item.dc:creator: Baris Balci

media:content.media:description: Shoppers in the Grand Bazaar in Istanbul. Photographer: Kerem Uzel/Bloomberg

item.title: Some ECB Officials Saw April Rate Cut as Frontloading June Move
item.description: April’s reduction in borrowing costs was considered by some European Central Bank officials as bringing forward a cut that had earlier been expected to come in June, according to an account of the meeting.
item.dc:creator: Jana Randow, Mark Schroers, Alexander Weber

item.title: South Africa to Provide $2.8 Billion Guarantee to Transnet
item.description: South Africa’s transport and finance ministries have approved a 51 billion-rand ($2.8 billion) guarantee facility to Transnet SOC Ltd., the nation’s struggling rail and ports operator.
item.dc:creator: Monique Vanek

media:content.media:description: Transnet freight trains at a depot in Gauteng, South Africa.

item.title: From Wealth Management to Tourism, the Gulf Reimagines Its Role
item.description: I’m Chris Anstey, an economics editor in Boston. Today we’re looking at ways that the Gulf region’s role in the world is shifting. Send us feedback and tips to ecodaily@bloomberg.net. And if you aren’t yet signed up to receive this newsletter, you can do so here.
item.dc:creator: Chris Anstey

item.title: Tariff Filing Burden, Audit Reviews Bog Down US Importers
item.description: Attention, IRS auditors. Tariff inspectors from US Customs and Border Protection are gaining on you in the race to be the most-feared federal regulators trying to ensure American businesses file paperwork correctly.
item.dc:creator: Brendan Murray

media:content.media:description: "USAID" etched onto a covering where signage used to be at the US Agency for International Development (USAID) headquarters in Washington, DC, US, on Monday, March 10, 2025. A US judge ordered the Trump administration to undo some of its cuts to billions of dollars in foreign assistance programs through the US Agency for International Development, the latest turn in a legal fight that’s likely to end up at the US Supreme Court. Photographer: Kent Nishimura/Bloomberg

item.title: RBA Ready to Respond If Needed to Trade Shock, Hauser Says
item.description: Australia’s central bank is ready to respond with policy in the event of deepening global fallout from the Trump administration’s tariff regime, Deputy Governor Andrew Hauser said, adding that there are few signs of any local impact at this stage.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

media:content.media:description: Andrew Hause speaks at the Lowy Institute in Sydney on May 22.

item.title: German Business Expectations Improve as Trade Fears Ease
item.description: German companies’ economic outlook improved as concern over President Donald Trump’s trade policy eased and an imminent boost to public spending buoyed sentiment.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers

media:content.media:description: Commuters in Stuttgart, Germany. Photographer: Krisztian Bocsi/Bloomberg

item.title: German Wage Growth Slows Sharply as Economy Struggles to Grow
item.description: German wage growth has eased significantly, and economic weakness suggests future deals will likely be much lower than in the past, according to the Bundesbank.
item.dc:creator: Jana Randow

media:content.media:description: Welders work on a railroad car, in Saxony-Anhalt.

item.title: Japan’s Largest Business Lobby Reports Pay Hikes Exceeding 5%
item.description: Japan’s top business lobby reported that workers at affiliated companies won pledges for pay hikes exceeding 5% for a second consecutive year, an outcome that points to continued momentum in wage increases fueled by the worsening labor crunch.
item.dc:creator: Erica Yokoyama

item.title: Euro-Zone Private Sector Unexpectedly Shrinks on Services
item.description: Private-sector activity in the euro area unexpectedly shrank in May as services recorded their worst performance in 16 months.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers

media:content.media:description: A warehouse near the Roissy district of Paris, France. Photographer: Marlene Awaad/Bloomberg

item.title: It’s ‘Crunch Time’ for US Importers Facing Tariff Deadlines, Customs Audits
item.description: US businesses are under mounting pressure to import goods while President Donald Trump’s higher tariffs are on pause, and they’re simultaneously navigating increasingly complex filing rules when their cargo crosses the border.
item.dc:creator: Enda Curran, Brendan Murray

media:content.media:description: A container ship passes under the International Gateway Bridge at the Port of Long Beach in Long Beach, California, US, on Monday, June 17, 2024. Inflation looks to be easing across the developed world, except for one glaring pocket of hot prices: cargo costs on the high seas. Spot rates for full-size shipping containers to the US and Europe from Asia rose again in the most recent data.

item.title: ECB’s Vujcic Says Inflation Is Slowly Converging to 2% Target
item.description: European Central Bank Governing Council member Boris Vujcic said consumer-price growth is heading toward the 2% goal.
item.dc:creator: Jasmina Kuzmanovic

media:content.media:description: Boris Vujcic, governor of the Croatian National Bank, during a panel session at the Ten Years Of Euro In Latvia conference in Riga, Latvia on Friday, Jan. 26, 2024. The conference brings policy makers, experts and civil society representatives who played a pivotal role in the introduction of the euro all across Europe and specifically in Latvia. Photographer: Andrey Rudakov/Bloomberg

item.title: UK Private Sector Shrinks Again as US Tariffs Hit, PMI Shows
item.description: The UK private sector contracted again in May as Donald Trump’s tariffs hit demand from abroad, according to a closely watched survey, raising the stakes for the government’s US trade deal.
item.dc:creator: Irina Anghel

item.title: UK Budget Deficit Widened in April Despite Employer Tax Hike
item.description: UK government borrowing increased in the first month of the new fiscal year, providing Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves little relief from the difficult budget backdrop she has faced since taking office.
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick

media:content.media:description: The headquarters of HM Treasury in the Westminster district of London. Photographer: Hollie Adams/Bloomberg

item.title: Why Interest Rates Are Shooting Up All Around the World
item.description: The big bond market selloff.
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

media:content.media:description: The US Treasury Department in Washington, DC.
